How can it be studied across different cultures? This course takes as its premise that melodrama is at once a prevalent mode throughout film history and a powerful expressive form addressing significant social changes and historical experiences. Focusing on the post World War II period up to the 1960s, the course examines the proliferation and transformation of melodrama film within various national, sub-national, postcolonial and global contexts. Screenings include films from Asia and Europe as well as the U.S., such as: Letter from an Unknown Woman , Imitation of Life , Tokyo Story , Love is a Many-Splendored Thing , Devdas , Stage Sisters . Screen Melodrama: Global Perspectives: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Department of Cinema Studies _Copy Undergraduate Graduate MIAP Home Dual BA/MA Program Asian Film and Media Initiative (AFMI) Certificate in Culture and Media Financial Aid and Scholarships Course Offerings News & Events Faculty & Administration Alumni Cinema Resources Blog Announcements  home > Cinema Studies        Screen Melodrama: Global Perspectives  Event Date and Time:    February 28, 2013 – March 3, 2013 Thursday: 6:30pm, Friday-Saturday: 9:00am - 10:00pm, Sunday: 9:00am - 6:00pm    Location:    Thurs and Sat: Columbia University; Fri and Sun: New York University    A four-day international conference jointly organized by NYU's Department of Cinema Studies and the Columbia Film Program.    This conference will reflect upon the implications of global melodrama for understanding transnational popular cultures, and explore the consequent need to re-conceptualize melodrama and its origins.    Co-sponsored by:    -NYU Humanities Initiative -Sites of Cinema Columbia Seminars -the Asian Film and Media Initiative @ NYU Cinema Studies -Filmoteca de la UNAM, Mexico City -Mexican Cultural
